ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: How to integrate and determine convergence of series
Calc 2
I learned so much calculus! From series to convergence, over the course of the term, I improved and better understood the material.
I learned the fundamentals of Calculus 2 including integration of series, shapes, polar areas, etc.
I learned the fundamental concepts covered in AP Calculus BC.
I gained more calculus knowledge.
how to approach problems in new ways
A solid understanding of integral calculus
We covered integration strategies, solids of revolution, sequences and series, parametric equations, and polar coordinates.
Integration techniques, application of integrations and evaluating series
I learned some more calculus
I learned about skills relating to integration, convergence of series, and polar and parametric equations.
My calculus skills have certainly improved during this course. I expect what I have learned will be immensely valuable to me as I study higher-level economics.
I took calculus before this course, including integral calculus but I feel as though this course truly expanded and solidified my skills.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course is well organized.

I enjoyed the online Canvas explorations and the Professor Demers videos. The course material videos were similar to Khan Academy videos and were helpful. A weakness of this course is that the test material does not always reflect the level of difficulty or the type of problems reviewed in class.
I think the course is pretty straightforward. All the course material was useful.

Strength: I felt that the course was relatively well structured and that the psets aligned with what we learned during previous lectures. Weaknesses: The course was extremely fast-paced, and had I not taken AP Calc BC in high school, I would have been very lost. I also didnt love how each class period was structured, with short lectures followed by collaborative exercises that we worked on together. I think lectures in which the professor worked through problems in front of us would have been more effective because our class did not work together, and class periods were often filled with awkward, silent stretches.
I think the course is organized nicely in canvas, but it would be nice if concepts were taught/introduced more in class rather than in the canvas videos.
strengths: interesting content. weakness: a little disorganized
Strength: the exams were reflective of the problem sets. they gave us good guidance on how to study for exam. no weakness.

Strengths: the pacing is reasonable, the material is actually pretty interesting, and there are many resources in place to help students succeed (office hours, review sessions before midterms and the final, peer tutoring).
Weaknesses: how well the content gets covered depends completely on your TF, the PSets are pretty frequent and the content we need to know to do them often gets covered 1 or 2 days before they're due.
More interactive activities in class
The information was clear but could have been more interactive

Some strengths of this course include its emphasis on the students having to do a lot of their work by themselves (and as a result there is increased collaboration).
However, it would be extremely useful to have more in-class demonstrations in the way the explorations (homework before each class )were.

Many of the seminars are taught by graduate students. To put it simply, they lack experience teaching and the students tend to suffer as a result. Students in sections taught by actual professors are at a significant advantage. I believe I had to work much harder and my understanding of the material suffered as a result. I know not much can be done about this issue, but I would suggest that maybe Brett's class be recorded for students in other sections to watch as additional help. I can personally say I know I would have benefited from that.

It was clear and organized. I think sometimes the explorations or interactive digital things detracted from the course. I think more visual aspects could have been introduced, however, in the revolutions of a solid unit.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Not unless it is a requirement for your major
Yes
This course is required for so many majors, so I would recommend it to those potentially interested.
Yes, if you need a straightforward math credit and want to understand calc 2.
Only if you need it as a pre-req.
I would only recommend this course to those who must take it as a requirement or to those who genuinely enjoy math.
Sure
Yes - if you are interested in calc or need a prerequisite.

Yes I would. Even as a humanities-oriented person, I really enjoyed many of the concepts we covered. The workload is also very reasonable once you fall into a routine (like doing the Explorations for the week the weekend before, and also starting the pset during the weekend). I also felt that the psets got easier over the course of the semester.
This course is good for learning fundamental math concepts for later courses
Yes, if it is a requirement

Most likely, I would not. Unless they are someone who greatly enjoys mathematics or its applications or needs the class to complete a credit, I did not find the class interesting and it often caused me more stress than it did enrich my life. I did enjoy the occasional videos on real world applications though (to be specific, there were videos relating to Professor Demers and that content specifically was interesting).
Yes if you need it as a prerequisite for other courses. I personally wouldn't take it otherwise.
Yes, it is a very good foundation. Even if you took calculus in high school I recommend this course unless you feel really really solid.
